awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Nanoscale sensing and imaging using computational single-molecule nanoscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Visualizing the Interactions between Individual Molecules within Cell Membranes Using Chemical Probes, Computation, and Microscopy

The membrane of a cell separates its internal contents, such as organelles, DNA, and proteins, from its environment and therefore controls how chemical signals (e.g., molecules) are sent to and received from other cells. Existing imaging technologies struggle to visualize the nanoscale "wrinkles" and roughness of these membranes due to their small sizes and fast fluctuations. This project will develop a synergistic approach called computational single-molecule nanoscopy that combines optical hardware, image processing software, and molecular sensors for imaging living cells with nanoscale resolution. The proposed technology will visualize the electrical and chemical environments within membranes that govern how they work. Ultimately, this approach will enable scientists to study how nanoscale structures within the membrane influence how molecules are transported across the membrane, which could be useful for the design of nanomedicines that target and kill cancer cells. The PI will collaborate with the Saint Louis Science Center and the Washington University SPECTRA student group to promote the public's scientific and technological understanding of this research. Undergraduate and graduate students involved in the research program will obtain broad knowledge and diverse technical skills in applied physics, optics, spectroscopy, estimation theory, image processing, and biology. These students will receive a unique and comprehensive preparation for modern careers in technology innovation and scientific discovery.

The proposed research will develop an integrated chemical, optical, and computational technology, termed computational single-molecule nanoscopy, for sensing and imaging the electrical and chemical properties of cell membranes with nanoscale resolution. The research approach is 1) to investigate the resolution and sensitivity limits of computational optical nanoscopy for measuring nanoscale information; 2) to quantify the performance of fluorescent molecules for sensing the electrical and chemical properties of their nano-environments; and 3) to visualize lipid rafts within cell membranes to determine how they regulate the trafficking of biomolecules across the membrane. The merit of the proposed work lies in innovatively exploiting the synergy between fluorescent molecules and optical microscopes. Rather than simply using fluorescent molecules as beacons that report a biomolecule's location, as current methods do now, the fluorescence emitted by rapidly-diffusing molecules will be used to measure the polarity and fluidity of a nano-environment. To harness the information reported by these molecules, new optical systems and image processing algorithms will be jointly designed to maximize the precision and sensitivity of nanoscale measurements in the presence of noise. Sensing the nanoscale properties of cell membranes will provide new insight into intercellular communication: how electrical, chemical, and mechanical signals propagate between cells and across their membranes.

por.por_cntn:
The PI's long-term career goal is to study molecular activities and interactions at the nanoscale and how they influence the dynamics of systems composed of many molecules. This project, entitled "CAREER: Nanoscale sensing and imaging using computational single-molecule nanoscopy," has achieved the first steps towards this goal. Several notable outcomes helped advance knowledge at the intersection of integrated sensing and computational systems and nanoscale biology. In particular:

 

1)     The project developed several advanced computational nanoscopes, i.e., optical microscopes capable of achieving nanoscale resolution, and investigated the limits of their resolution and sensitivity.

Several new imaging technologies were developed to measure the 2D or 3D positions and 3D orientations of molecules, called 5D and 6D nanoscopy, both in vitro and within cells with nanoscale resolution. The newly developed tri-spot microscope received a patent in 2020, while the duo-spot and multi-view reflector microscopes feature upgraded performance and have patents under review. These technologies advanced our knowledge in designing imaging systems that integrate physics and computation for improved performance; in these cases, five and six-dimensional imaging of single molecules are now possible using the data provided by conventional two-dimensional cameras. Theories developed during this project have established the exact performance limits that constrain all possible imaging system designs, and they also revealed fundamental biases in measurements of molecular orientation that have not been characterized before. Importantly, this project demonstrates high-dimensional imaging even when extremely dim emitters are used, thereby enabling new scientific directions to be explored.

 

2)     The project established the ability of individual fluorescent molecules to sense chemical environments with nanoscale resolution.

This project revealed that the rotational motions of several fluorogenic dyes, i.e., molecules whose fluorescence responds to their chemical environments, e.g., Nile red, Nile blue, and merocyanine 540, can be used for nanoscale sensing. Nile red and Nile blue were found to bind transiently along the grooves formed by antiparallel beta sheets within amyloid-beta fibrils, which are signatures of Alzheimer's Disease. Using computational nanoscopy, the organization and architecture of various amyloid fibrils and networks of fibers were mapped. Nile red and merocyanine 540 were also used to "fingerprint" the chemical environments within lipid membranes. Precise 5D imaging revealed that NR exhibits a ~4° change in polar orientation and a ~0.3π sr change in rotational "wobble" within ordered lipid bilayers versus disordered bilayers. Thus, this project established the ability of computational nanoscopy to visualize organizational and functional dynamics of lipid-lipid, lipid-protein, and lipid-dye interactions with single-molecule, nanoscale resolution.

 

3)     The project demonstrated the ability of computational nanoscopy to visualize dynamics in the fluidity and organization of cell membranes.

Using the duo-spot microscope, newly developed during this project, changes in lipid bilayer composition facilitated by enzymes were monitored with nanoscale resolution by imaging changes in the orientations of Nile red. These images revealed spatially heterogenous enzyme activity using fewer total single-molecule blinking events than conventional super-resolution imaging, thereby opening the door to faster nanoscale imaging in the future. Using a microscope with radially and azimuthally polarized detection channels, this project discovered that rotational and translational motions of fluorescent molecules sense separate environmental properties of lipid membranes, thereby establishing the need for 5D computational nanoscopy over standard 2D and 3D super-resolution microscopy. By precisely measuring changes in lateral displacements and orientational diffusion, this project revealed pockets of membrane that were degraded by enzyme activity.

 

The project also benefited society by achieving the following outcomes:

 

4)     This project has facilitated student contributions to scientific research and discovery.

All graduate and undergraduate students participating in the research efforts of this project have successfully submitted abstracts for oral presentations at various international conferences, with all of them publishing first-authored papers in peer-reviewed scientific journals. Students have received training in and contributed knowledge to a broad range of disciplines, including signal processing, estimation theory, computational optical imaging, quantum mechanics, amyloid protein biochemistry, and lipid biophysics. 

 

5)     This project has facilitated the training of junior scientists to effectively communicate with the public.

Student participation in the Portal to the Public training gave them the skills needed to teach their research in an informal learning environment and inspire positive attitudes toward science and engineering. After completing this training, students are able to engage in brief interactions with hundreds of people attending expos at the Saint Louis Science Center, inspiring young people to pursue science learning, and inspiring confidence in the scientific process across all ages.
